lines: [Enter SHALLOW, SLENDER, and SIR HUGH EVANS]

blocks.speaker: shallow
lines: Sir Hugh, persuade me not; I will make a Star-
chamber matter of it: if he were twenty Sir John
Falstaffs, he shall not abuse Robert Shallow, esquire.

blocks.speaker: slender
lines: In the county of Gloucester, justice of peace and
'Coram.'

blocks.speaker: shallow
lines: Ay, cousin Slender, and 'Custalourum.

blocks.speaker: slender
lines: Ay, and 'Rato-lorum' too; and a gentleman born,
master parson; who writes himself 'Armigero,' in any
bill, warrant, quittance, or obligation, 'Armigero.'

blocks.speaker: shallow
lines: Ay, that I do; and have done any time these three
hundred years.

blocks.speaker: slender
lines: All his successors gone before him hath done't; and
all his ancestors that come after him may: they may
give the dozen white luces in their coat.

blocks.speaker: shallow
lines: It is an old coat.

blocks.speaker: sirhugh
lines: The dozen white louses do become an old coat well;
it agrees well, passant; it is a familiar beast to
man, and signifies love.

blocks.speaker: shallow
lines: The luce is the fresh fish; the salt fish is an old coat.

blocks.speaker: slender
lines: I may quarter, coz.

blocks.speaker: shallow
lines: You may, by marrying.

blocks.speaker: sirhugh
lines: It is marring indeed, if he quarter it.

blocks.speaker: shallow
lines: Not a whit.

blocks.speaker: sirhugh
lines: Yes, py'r lady; if he has a quarter of your coat,
there is but three skirts for yourself, in my
simple conjectures: but that is all one. If Sir
John Falstaff have committed disparagements unto
you, I am of the church, and will be glad to do my
benevolence to make atonements and compremises
between you.

blocks.speaker: shallow
lines: The council shall bear it; it is a riot.

blocks.speaker: sirhugh
lines: It is not meet the council hear a riot; there is no
fear of Got in a riot: the council, look you, shall
desire to hear the fear of Got, and not to hear a
riot; take your vizaments in that.

blocks.speaker: shallow
lines: Ha! o' my life, if I were young again, the sword
should end it.

blocks.speaker: sirhugh
lines: It is petter that friends is the sword, and end it:
and there is also another device in my prain, which
peradventure prings goot discretions with it: there
is Anne Page, which is daughter to Master Thomas
Page, which is pretty virginity.

blocks.speaker: slender
lines: Mistress Anne Page? She has brown hair, and speaks
small like a woman.

blocks.speaker: sirhugh
lines: It is that fery person for all the orld, as just as
you will desire; and seven hundred pounds of moneys,
and gold and silver, is her grandsire upon his
death's-bed--Got deliver to a joyful resurrections!
--give, when she is able to overtake seventeen years
old: it were a goot motion if we leave our pribbles
and prabbles, and desire a marriage between Master
Abraham and Mistress Anne Page.

blocks.speaker: slender
lines: Did her grandsire leave her seven hundred pound?

blocks.speaker: sirhugh
lines: Ay, and her father is make her a petter penny.

blocks.speaker: slender
lines: I know the young gentlewoman; she has good gifts.

blocks.speaker: sirhugh
lines: Seven hundred pounds and possibilities is goot gifts.

blocks.speaker: shallow
lines: Well, let us see honest Master Page. Is Falstaff there?

blocks.speaker: sirhugh
lines: Shall I tell you a lie? I do despise a liar as I do
despise one that is false, or as I despise one that
is not true. The knight, Sir John, is there; and, I
beseech you, be ruled by your well-willers. I will
peat the door for Master Page.
[Knocks]
What, hoa! Got pless your house here!

blocks.speaker: page-mww
lines: [Within] Who's there?
[Enter PAGE]

blocks.speaker: sirhugh
lines: Here is Got's plessing, and your friend, and Justice
Shallow; and here young Master Slender, that
peradventures shall tell you another tale, if
matters grow to your likings.

blocks.speaker: page-mww
lines: I am glad to see your worships well.
I thank you for my venison, Master Shallow.

blocks.speaker: shallow
lines: Master Page, I am glad to see you: much good do it
your good heart! I wished your venison better; it
was ill killed. How doth good Mistress Page?--and I
thank you always with my heart, la! with my heart.

blocks.speaker: page-mww
lines: Sir, I thank you.

blocks.speaker: shallow
lines: Sir, I thank you; by yea and no, I do.

blocks.speaker: page-mww
lines: I am glad to see you, good Master Slender.

blocks.speaker: slender
lines: How does your fallow greyhound, sir? I heard say he
was outrun on Cotsall.

blocks.speaker: page-mww
lines: It could not be judged, sir.

blocks.speaker: slender
lines: You'll not confess, you'll not confess.

blocks.speaker: shallow
lines: That he will not. 'Tis your fault, 'tis your fault;
'tis a good dog.

blocks.speaker: page-mww
lines: A cur, sir.

blocks.speaker: shallow
lines: Sir, he's a good dog, and a fair dog: can there be
more said? he is good and fair. Is Sir John
Falstaff here?

blocks.speaker: page-mww
lines: Sir, he is within; and I would I could do a good
office between you.

blocks.speaker: sirhugh
lines: It is spoke as a Christians ought to speak.

blocks.speaker: shallow
lines: He hath wronged me, Master Page.

blocks.speaker: page-mww
lines: Sir, he doth in some sort confess it.

blocks.speaker: shallow
lines: If it be confessed, it is not redress'd: is not that
so, Master Page? He hath wronged me; indeed he
hath, at a word, he hath, believe me: Robert
Shallow, esquire, saith, he is wronged.

blocks.speaker: page-mww
lines: Here comes Sir John.
[Enter FALSTAFF, BARDOLPH, NYM, and PISTOL]

blocks.speaker: falstaff
lines: Now, Master Shallow, you'll complain of me to the king?

blocks.speaker: shallow
lines: Knight, you have beaten my men, killed my deer, and
broke open my lodge.

blocks.speaker: falstaff
lines: But not kissed your keeper's daughter?

blocks.speaker: shallow
lines: Tut, a pin! this shall be answered.

blocks.speaker: falstaff
lines: I will answer it straight; I have done all this.
That is now answered.

blocks.speaker: shallow
lines: The council shall know this.

blocks.speaker: falstaff
lines: 'Twere better for you if it were known in counsel:
you'll be laughed at.

blocks.speaker: sirhugh
lines: Pauca verba, Sir John; goot worts.

blocks.speaker: falstaff
lines: Good worts! good cabbage. Slender, I broke your
head: what matter have you against me?

blocks.speaker: slender
lines: Marry, sir, I have matter in my head against you;
and against your cony-catching rascals, Bardolph,
Nym, and Pistol.

blocks.speaker: bardolph-mww
lines: You Banbury cheese!

blocks.speaker: slender
lines: Ay, it is no matter.

blocks.speaker: pistol
lines: How now, Mephostophilus!

blocks.speaker: slender
lines: Ay, it is no matter.

blocks.speaker: nym
lines: Slice, I say! pauca, pauca: slice! that's my humour.

blocks.speaker: slender
lines: Where's Simple, my man? Can you tell, cousin?

blocks.speaker: sirhugh
lines: Peace, I pray you. Now let us understand. There is
three umpires in this matter, as I understand; that
is, Master Page, fidelicet Master Page; and there is
myself, fidelicet myself; and the three party is,
lastly and finally, mine host of the Garter.

blocks.speaker: page-mww
lines: We three, to hear it and end it between them.

blocks.speaker: sirhugh
lines: Fery goot: I will make a prief of it in my note-
book; and we will afterwards ork upon the cause with
as great discreetly as we can.

blocks.speaker: falstaff
lines: Pistol!

blocks.speaker: pistol
lines: He hears with ears.

blocks.speaker: sirhugh
lines: The tevil and his tam! what phrase is this, 'He
hears with ear'? why, it is affectations.

blocks.speaker: falstaff
lines: Pistol, did you pick Master Slender's purse?

blocks.speaker: slender
lines: Ay, by these gloves, did he, or I would I might
never come in mine own great chamber again else, of
seven groats in mill-sixpences, and two Edward
shovel-boards, that cost me two shilling and two
pence apiece of Yead Miller, by these gloves.

blocks.speaker: falstaff
lines: Is this true, Pistol?

blocks.speaker: sirhugh
lines: No; it is false, if it is a pick-purse.

blocks.speaker: pistol
lines: Ha, thou mountain-foreigner! Sir John and Master mine,
I combat challenge of this latten bilbo.
Word of denial in thy labras here!
Word of denial: froth and scum, thou liest!

blocks.speaker: slender
lines: By these gloves, then, 'twas he.

blocks.speaker: nym
lines: Be avised, sir, and pass good humours: I will say
'marry trap' with you, if you run the nuthook's
humour on me; that is the very note of it.

blocks.speaker: slender
lines: By this hat, then, he in the red face had it; for
though I cannot remember what I did when you made me
drunk, yet I am not altogether an ass.

blocks.speaker: falstaff
lines: What say you, Scarlet and John?

blocks.speaker: bardolph-mww
lines: Why, sir, for my part I say the gentleman had drunk
himself out of his five sentences.

blocks.speaker: sirhugh
lines: It is his five senses: fie, what the ignorance is!

blocks.speaker: bardolph-mww
lines: And being fap, sir, was, as they say, cashiered; and
so conclusions passed the careires.

blocks.speaker: slender
lines: Ay, you spake in Latin then too; but 'tis no
matter: I'll ne'er be drunk whilst I live again,
but in honest, civil, godly company, for this trick:
if I be drunk, I'll be drunk with those that have
the fear of God, and not with drunken knaves.

blocks.speaker: sirhugh
lines: So Got udge me, that is a virtuous mind.

blocks.speaker: falstaff
lines: You hear all these matters denied, gentlemen; you hear it.
[Enter ANNE PAGE, with wine; MISTRESS FORD]
and MISTRESS PAGE, following]

blocks.speaker: page-mww
lines: Nay, daughter, carry the wine in; we'll drink within.
[Exit ANNE PAGE]

blocks.speaker: slender
lines: O heaven! this is Mistress Anne Page.

blocks.speaker: page-mww
lines: How now, Mistress Ford!

blocks.speaker: falstaff
lines: Mistress Ford, by my troth, you are very well met:
by your leave, good mistress.
[Kisses her]

blocks.speaker: page-mww
lines: Wife, bid these gentlemen welcome. Come, we have a
hot venison pasty to dinner: come, gentlemen, I hope
we shall drink down all unkindness.
[Exeunt all except SHALLOW, SLENDER, and SIR HUGH EVANS]

blocks.speaker: slender
lines: I had rather than forty shillings I had my Book of
Songs and Sonnets here.
[Enter SIMPLE]
How now, Simple! where have you been? I must wait
on myself, must I? You have not the Book of Riddles
about you, have you?

blocks.speaker: simple
lines: Book of Riddles! why, did you not lend it to Alice
Shortcake upon All-hallowmas last, a fortnight
afore Michaelmas?

blocks.speaker: shallow
lines: Come, coz; come, coz; we stay for you. A word with
you, coz; marry, this, coz: there is, as 'twere, a
tender, a kind of tender, made afar off by Sir Hugh
here. Do you understand me?

blocks.speaker: slender
lines: Ay, sir, you shall find me reasonable; if it be so,
I shall do that that is reason.

blocks.speaker: shallow
lines: Nay, but understand me.

blocks.speaker: slender
lines: So I do, sir.

blocks.speaker: sirhugh
lines: Give ear to his motions, Master Slender: I will
description the matter to you, if you be capacity of it.

blocks.speaker: slender
lines: Nay, I will do as my cousin Shallow says: I pray
you, pardon me; he's a justice of peace in his
country, simple though I stand here.

blocks.speaker: sirhugh
lines: But that is not the question: the question is
concerning your marriage.

blocks.speaker: shallow
lines: Ay, there's the point, sir.

blocks.speaker: sirhugh
lines: Marry, is it; the very point of it; to Mistress Anne Page.

blocks.speaker: slender
lines: Why, if it be so, I will marry her upon any
reasonable demands.

blocks.speaker: sirhugh
lines: But can you affection the 'oman? Let us command to
know that of your mouth or of your lips; for divers
philosophers hold that the lips is parcel of the
mouth. Therefore, precisely, can you carry your
good will to the maid?

blocks.speaker: shallow
lines: Cousin Abraham Slender, can you love her?

blocks.speaker: slender
lines: I hope, sir, I will do as it shall become one that
would do reason.

blocks.speaker: sirhugh
lines: Nay, Got's lords and his ladies! you must speak
possitable, if you can carry her your desires
towards her.

blocks.speaker: shallow
lines: That you must. Will you, upon good dowry, marry her?

blocks.speaker: slender
lines: I will do a greater thing than that, upon your
request, cousin, in any reason.

blocks.speaker: shallow
lines: Nay, conceive me, conceive me, sweet coz: what I do
is to pleasure you, coz. Can you love the maid?

blocks.speaker: slender
lines: I will marry her, sir, at your request: but if there
be no great love in the beginning, yet heaven may
decrease it upon better acquaintance, when we are
married and have more occasion to know one another;
I hope, upon familiarity will grow more contempt:
but if you say, 'Marry her,' I will marry her; that
I am freely dissolved, and dissolutely.

blocks.speaker: sirhugh
lines: It is a fery discretion answer; save the fall is in
the ort 'dissolutely:' the ort is, according to our
meaning, 'resolutely:' his meaning is good.

blocks.speaker: shallow
lines: Ay, I think my cousin meant well.

blocks.speaker: slender
lines: Ay, or else I would I might be hanged, la!

blocks.speaker: shallow
lines: Here comes fair Mistress Anne.
[Re-enter ANNE PAGE]
Would I were young for your sake, Mistress Anne!

blocks.speaker: annepage
lines: The dinner is on the table; my father desires your
worships' company.

blocks.speaker: shallow
lines: I will wait on him, fair Mistress Anne.

blocks.speaker: sirhugh
lines: Od's plessed will! I will not be absence at the grace.
[Exeunt SHALLOW and SIR HUGH EVANS]

blocks.speaker: annepage
lines: Will't please your worship to come in, sir?

blocks.speaker: slender
lines: No, I thank you, forsooth, heartily; I am very well.

blocks.speaker: annepage
lines: The dinner attends you, sir.

blocks.speaker: slender
lines: I am not a-hungry, I thank you, forsooth. Go,
sirrah, for all you are my man, go wait upon my
cousin Shallow.
[Exit SIMPLE]
A justice of peace sometimes may be beholding to his
friend for a man. I keep but three men and a boy
yet, till my mother be dead: but what though? Yet I
live like a poor gentleman born.

blocks.speaker: annepage
lines: I may not go in without your worship: they will not
sit till you come.

blocks.speaker: slender
lines: I' faith, I'll eat nothing; I thank you as much as
though I did.

blocks.speaker: annepage
lines: I pray you, sir, walk in.

blocks.speaker: slender
lines: I had rather walk here, I thank you. I bruised
my shin th' other day with playing at sword and
dagger with a master of fence; three veneys for a
dish of stewed prunes; and, by my troth, I cannot
abide the smell of hot meat since. Why do your
dogs bark so? be there bears i' the town?

blocks.speaker: annepage
lines: I think there are, sir; I heard them talked of.

blocks.speaker: slender
lines: I love the sport well but I shall as soon quarrel at
it as any man in England. You are afraid, if you see
the bear loose, are you not?

blocks.speaker: annepage
lines: Ay, indeed, sir.

blocks.speaker: slender
lines: That's meat and drink to me, now. I have seen
Sackerson loose twenty times, and have taken him by
the chain; but, I warrant you, the women have so
cried and shrieked at it, that it passed: but women,
indeed, cannot abide 'em; they are very ill-favored
rough things.
[Re-enter PAGE]

blocks.speaker: page-mww
lines: Come, gentle Master Slender, come; we stay for you.

blocks.speaker: slender
lines: I'll eat nothing, I thank you, sir.

blocks.speaker: page-mww
lines: By cock and pie, you shall not choose, sir! come, come.

blocks.speaker: slender
lines: Nay, pray you, lead the way.

blocks.speaker: page-mww
lines: Come on, sir.

blocks.speaker: slender
lines: Mistress Anne, yourself shall go first.

blocks.speaker: annepage
lines: Not I, sir; pray you, keep on.

blocks.speaker: slender
lines: I'll rather be unmannerly than troublesome.
You do yourself wrong, indeed, la!
[Exeunt]
[Enter SIR HUGH EVANS and SIMPLE]

blocks.speaker: sirhugh
lines: Go your ways, and ask of Doctor Caius' house which
is the way: and there dwells one Mistress Quickly,
which is in the manner of his nurse, or his dry
nurse, or his cook, or his laundry, his washer, and
his wringer.

blocks.speaker: simple
lines: Well, sir.

blocks.speaker: sirhugh
lines: Nay, it is petter yet. Give her this letter; for it
is a 'oman that altogether's acquaintance with
Mistress Anne Page: and the letter is, to desire
and require her to solicit your master's desires to
Mistress Anne Page. I pray you, be gone: I will
make an end of my dinner; there's pippins and cheese to come.
[Exeunt]
[Enter FALSTAFF, Host, BARDOLPH, NYM, PISTOL,]
and ROBIN]

scenes.title: A room in the Garter Inn.

blocks.speaker: falstaff
lines: Mine host of the Garter!

blocks.speaker: garterhost
lines: What says my bully-rook? speak scholarly and wisely.

blocks.speaker: falstaff
lines: Truly, mine host, I must turn away some of my
followers.

blocks.speaker: garterhost
lines: Discard, bully Hercules; cashier: let them wag; trot, trot.

blocks.speaker: falstaff
lines: I sit at ten pounds a week.

blocks.speaker: garterhost
lines: Thou'rt an emperor, Caesar, Keisar, and Pheezar. I
will entertain Bardolph; he shall draw, he shall
tap: said I well, bully Hector?

blocks.speaker: falstaff
lines: Do so, good mine host.

blocks.speaker: garterhost
lines: I have spoke; let him follow.
[To BARDOLPH]
Let me see thee froth and lime: I am at a word; follow.
[Exit]

blocks.speaker: falstaff
lines: Bardolph, follow him. A tapster is a good trade:
an old cloak makes a new jerkin; a withered
serving-man a fresh tapster. Go; adieu.

blocks.speaker: bardolph-mww
lines: It is a life that I have desired: I will thrive.

blocks.speaker: pistol
lines: O base Hungarian wight! wilt thou the spigot wield?
[Exit BARDOLPH]

blocks.speaker: nym
lines: He was gotten in drink: is not the humour conceited?

blocks.speaker: falstaff
lines: I am glad I am so acquit of this tinderbox: his
thefts were too open; his filching was like an
unskilful singer; he kept not time.

blocks.speaker: nym
lines: The good humour is to steal at a minute's rest.

blocks.speaker: pistol
lines: 'Convey,' the wise it call. 'Steal!' foh! a fico
for the phrase!

blocks.speaker: falstaff
lines: Well, sirs, I am almost out at heels.

blocks.speaker: pistol
lines: Why, then, let kibes ensue.

blocks.speaker: falstaff
lines: There is no remedy; I must cony-catch; I must shift.

blocks.speaker: pistol
lines: Young ravens must have food.

blocks.speaker: falstaff
lines: Which of you know Ford of this town?

blocks.speaker: pistol
lines: I ken the wight: he is of substance good.

blocks.speaker: falstaff
lines: My honest lads, I will tell you what I am about.

blocks.speaker: pistol
lines: Two yards, and more.

blocks.speaker: falstaff
lines: No quips now, Pistol! Indeed, I am in the waist two
yards about; but I am now about no waste; I am about
thrift. Briefly, I do mean to make love to Ford's
wife: I spy entertainment in her; she discourses,
she carves, she gives the leer of invitation: I
can construe the action of her familiar style; and
the hardest voice of her behavior, to be Englished
rightly, is, 'I am Sir John Falstaff's.'

blocks.speaker: pistol
lines: He hath studied her will, and translated her will,
out of honesty into English.

blocks.speaker: nym
lines: The anchor is deep: will that humour pass?

blocks.speaker: falstaff
lines: Now, the report goes she has all the rule of her
husband's purse: he hath a legion of angels.

blocks.speaker: pistol
lines: As many devils entertain; and 'To her, boy,' say I.

blocks.speaker: nym
lines: The humour rises; it is good: humour me the angels.

blocks.speaker: falstaff
lines: I have writ me here a letter to her: and here
another to Page's wife, who even now gave me good
eyes too, examined my parts with most judicious
oeillades; sometimes the beam of her view gilded my
foot, sometimes my portly belly.

blocks.speaker: pistol
lines: Then did the sun on dunghill shine.

blocks.speaker: nym
lines: I thank thee for that humour.

blocks.speaker: falstaff
lines: O, she did so course o'er my exteriors with such a
greedy intention, that the appetite of her eye did
seem to scorch me up like a burning-glass! Here's
another letter to her: she bears the purse too; she
is a region in Guiana, all gold and bounty. I will
be cheater to them both, and they shall be
exchequers to me; they shall be my East and West
Indies, and I will trade to them both. Go bear thou
this letter to Mistress Page; and thou this to
Mistress Ford: we will thrive, lads, we will thrive.

blocks.speaker: pistol
lines: Shall I Sir Pandarus of Troy become,
And by my side wear steel? then, Lucifer take all!

blocks.speaker: nym
lines: I will run no base humour: here, take the
humour-letter: I will keep the havior of reputation.

blocks.speaker: falstaff
lines: [To ROBIN] Hold, sirrah, bear you these letters tightly;
Sail like my pinnace to these golden shores.
Rogues, hence, avaunt! vanish like hailstones, go;
Trudge, plod away o' the hoof; seek shelter, pack!
Falstaff will learn the humour of the age,
French thrift, you rogues; myself and skirted page.
[Exeunt FALSTAFF and ROBIN]

blocks.speaker: pistol
lines: Let vultures gripe thy guts! for gourd and fullam holds,
And high and low beguiles the rich and poor:
Tester I'll have in pouch when thou shalt lack,
Base Phrygian Turk!

blocks.speaker: nym
lines: I have operations which be humours of revenge.

blocks.speaker: pistol
lines: Wilt thou revenge?

blocks.speaker: nym
lines: By welkin and her star!

blocks.speaker: pistol
lines: With wit or steel?

blocks.speaker: nym
lines: With both the humours, I:
I will discuss the humour of this love to Page.

blocks.speaker: pistol
lines: And I to Ford shall eke unfold
How Falstaff, varlet vile,
His dove will prove, his gold will hold,
And his soft couch defile.

blocks.speaker: nym
lines: My humour shall not cool: I will incense Page to
deal with poison; I will possess him with
yellowness, for the revolt of mine is dangerous:
that is my true humour.

blocks.speaker: pistol
lines: Thou art the Mars of malecontents: I second thee; troop on.
[Exeunt]

scenes.title: A room in DOCTOR CAIUS’ house.

lines: [Enter MISTRESS QUICKLY, SIMPLE, and RUGBY]

blocks.speaker: quickly
lines: What, John Rugby! I pray thee, go to the casement,
and see if you can see my master, Master Doctor
Caius, coming. If he do, i' faith, and find any
body in the house, here will be an old abusing of
God's patience and the king's English.

blocks.speaker: rugby
lines: I'll go watch.

blocks.speaker: quickly
lines: Go; and we'll have a posset for't soon at night, in
faith, at the latter end of a sea-coal fire.
[Exit RUGBY]
An honest, willing, kind fellow, as ever servant
shall come in house withal, and, I warrant you, no
tell-tale nor no breed-bate: his worst fault is,
that he is given to prayer; he is something peevish
that way: but nobody but has his fault; but let
that pass. Peter Simple, you say your name is?

blocks.speaker: simple
lines: Ay, for fault of a better.

blocks.speaker: quickly
lines: And Master Slender's your master?

blocks.speaker: simple
lines: Ay, forsooth.

blocks.speaker: quickly
lines: Does he not wear a great round beard, like a
glover's paring-knife?

blocks.speaker: simple
lines: No, forsooth: he hath but a little wee face, with a
little yellow beard, a Cain-coloured beard.

blocks.speaker: quickly
lines: A softly-sprighted man, is he not?

blocks.speaker: simple
lines: Ay, forsooth: but he is as tall a man of his hands
as any is between this and his head; he hath fought
with a warrener.

blocks.speaker: quickly
lines: How say you? O, I should remember him: does he not
hold up his head, as it were, and strut in his gait?

blocks.speaker: simple
lines: Yes, indeed, does he.

blocks.speaker: quickly
lines: Well, heaven send Anne Page no worse fortune! Tell
Master Parson Evans I will do what I can for your
master: Anne is a good girl, and I wish--
[Re-enter RUGBY]

blocks.speaker: rugby
lines: Out, alas! here comes my master.

blocks.speaker: quickly
lines: We shall all be shent. Run in here, good young man;
go into this closet: he will not stay long.
[Shuts SIMPLE in the closet]
What, John Rugby! John! what, John, I say!
Go, John, go inquire for my master; I doubt
he be not well, that he comes not home.
[Singing]
And down, down, adown-a, &c.
[Enter DOCTOR CAIUS]

blocks.speaker: doctorcaius
lines: Vat is you sing? I do not like des toys. Pray you,
go and vetch me in my closet un boitier vert, a box,
a green-a box: do intend vat I speak? a green-a box.

blocks.speaker: quickly
lines: Ay, forsooth; I'll fetch it you.
[Aside]
I am glad he went not in himself: if he had found
the young man, he would have been horn-mad.

blocks.speaker: doctorcaius
lines: Fe, fe, fe, fe! ma foi, il fait fort chaud. Je
m'en vais a la cour--la grande affaire.

blocks.speaker: quickly
lines: Is it this, sir?

blocks.speaker: doctorcaius
lines: Oui; mette le au mon pocket: depeche, quickly. Vere
is dat knave Rugby?

blocks.speaker: quickly
lines: What, John Rugby! John!

blocks.speaker: rugby
lines: Here, sir!

blocks.speaker: doctorcaius
lines: You are John Rugby, and you are Jack Rugby. Come,
take-a your rapier, and come after my heel to the court.

blocks.speaker: rugby
lines: 'Tis ready, sir, here in the porch.

blocks.speaker: doctorcaius
lines: By my trot, I tarry too long. Od's me!
Qu'ai-j'oublie! dere is some simples in my closet,
dat I vill not for the varld I shall leave behind.

blocks.speaker: quickly
lines: Ay me, he'll find the young man here, and be mad!

blocks.speaker: doctorcaius
lines: O diable, diable! vat is in my closet? Villain! larron!
[Pulling SIMPLE out]
Rugby, my rapier!

blocks.speaker: quickly
lines: Good master, be content.

blocks.speaker: doctorcaius
lines: Wherefore shall I be content-a?

blocks.speaker: quickly
lines: The young man is an honest man.

blocks.speaker: doctorcaius
lines: What shall de honest man do in my closet? dere is
no honest man dat shall come in my closet.

blocks.speaker: quickly
lines: I beseech you, be not so phlegmatic. Hear the truth
of it: he came of an errand to me from Parson Hugh.

blocks.speaker: doctorcaius
lines: Vell.

blocks.speaker: simple
lines: Ay, forsooth; to desire her to--

blocks.speaker: quickly
lines: Peace, I pray you.

blocks.speaker: doctorcaius
lines: Peace-a your tongue. Speak-a your tale.

blocks.speaker: simple
lines: To desire this honest gentlewoman, your maid, to
speak a good word to Mistress Anne Page for my
master in the way of marriage.

blocks.speaker: quickly
lines: This is all, indeed, la! but I'll ne'er put my
finger in the fire, and need not.

blocks.speaker: doctorcaius
lines: Sir Hugh send-a you? Rugby, baille me some paper.
Tarry you a little-a while.
[Writes]

blocks.speaker: quickly
lines: [Aside to SIMPLE] I am glad he is so quiet: if he
had been thoroughly moved, you should have heard him
so loud and so melancholy. But notwithstanding,
man, I'll do you your master what good I can: and
the very yea and the no is, the French doctor, my
master,--I may call him my master, look you, for I
keep his house; and I wash, wring, brew, bake,
scour, dress meat and drink, make the beds and do
all myself,--

blocks.speaker: simple
lines: [Aside to MISTRESS QUICKLY] 'Tis a great charge to
come under one body's hand.

blocks.speaker: quickly
lines: [Aside to SIMPLE] Are you avised o' that? you
shall find it a great charge: and to be up early
and down late; but notwithstanding,--to tell you in
your ear; I would have no words of it,--my master
himself is in love with Mistress Anne Page: but
notwithstanding that, I know Anne's mind,--that's
neither here nor there.

blocks.speaker: doctorcaius
lines: You jack'nape, give-a this letter to Sir Hugh; by
gar, it is a shallenge: I will cut his troat in dee
park; and I will teach a scurvy jack-a-nape priest
to meddle or make. You may be gone; it is not good
you tarry here. By gar, I will cut all his two
stones; by gar, he shall not have a stone to throw
at his dog:
[Exit SIMPLE]

blocks.speaker: quickly
lines: Alas, he speaks but for his friend.

blocks.speaker: doctorcaius
lines: It is no matter-a ver dat: do not you tell-a me
dat I shall have Anne Page for myself? By gar, I
vill kill de Jack priest; and I have appointed mine
host of de Jarteer to measure our weapon. By gar, I
will myself have Anne Page.

blocks.speaker: quickly
lines: Sir, the maid loves you, and all shall be well. We
must give folks leave to prate: what, the good-jer!

blocks.speaker: doctorcaius
lines: Rugby, come to the court with me. By gar, if I have
not Anne Page, I shall turn your head out of my
door. Follow my heels, Rugby.
[Exeunt DOCTOR CAIUS and RUGBY]

blocks.speaker: quickly
lines: You shall have An fool's-head of your own. No, I
know Anne's mind for that: never a woman in Windsor
knows more of Anne's mind than I do; nor can do more
than I do with her, I thank heaven.

blocks.speaker: fenton
lines: [Within] Who's within there? ho!

blocks.speaker: quickly
lines: Who's there, I trow! Come near the house, I pray you.
[Enter FENTON]

blocks.speaker: fenton
lines: How now, good woman? how dost thou?

blocks.speaker: quickly
lines: The better that it pleases your good worship to ask.

blocks.speaker: fenton
lines: What news? how does pretty Mistress Anne?

blocks.speaker: quickly
lines: In truth, sir, and she is pretty, and honest, and
gentle; and one that is your friend, I can tell you
that by the way; I praise heaven for it.

blocks.speaker: fenton
lines: Shall I do any good, thinkest thou? shall I not lose my suit?

blocks.speaker: quickly
lines: Troth, sir, all is in his hands above: but
notwithstanding, Master Fenton, I'll be sworn on a
book, she loves you. Have not your worship a wart
above your eye?

blocks.speaker: fenton
lines: Yes, marry, have I; what of that?

blocks.speaker: quickly
lines: Well, thereby hangs a tale: good faith, it is such
another Nan; but, I detest, an honest maid as ever
broke bread: we had an hour's talk of that wart. I
shall never laugh but in that maid's company! But
indeed she is given too much to allicholy and
musing: but for you--well, go to.

blocks.speaker: fenton
lines: Well, I shall see her to-day. Hold, there's money
for thee; let me have thy voice in my behalf: if
thou seest her before me, commend me.

blocks.speaker: quickly
lines: Will I? i'faith, that we will; and I will tell your
worship more of the wart the next time we have
confidence; and of other wooers.

blocks.speaker: fenton
lines: Well, farewell; I am in great haste now.

blocks.speaker: quickly
lines: Farewell to your worship.
[Exit FENTON]
Truly, an honest gentleman: but Anne loves him not;
for I know Anne's mind as well as another does. Out
upon't! what have I forgot?
[Exit]
[Enter MISTRESS PAGE, with a letter]

blocks.speaker: mistresspage
lines: What, have I scaped love-letters in the holiday-
time of my beauty, and am I now a subject for them?
Let me see.
[Reads]
'Ask me no reason why I love you; for though
Love use Reason for his physician, he admits him
not for his counsellor. You are not young, no more
am I; go to then, there's sympathy: you are merry,
so am I; ha, ha! then there's more sympathy: you
love sack, and so do I; would you desire better
sympathy? Let it suffice thee, Mistress Page,--at
the least, if the love of soldier can suffice,--
that I love thee. I will not say, pity me; 'tis
not a soldier-like phrase: but I say, love me. By me,
Thine own true knight,
By day or night,
Or any kind of light,
With all his might
For thee to fight, JOHN FALSTAFF'
What a Herod of Jewry is this! O wicked
world! One that is well-nigh worn to pieces with
age to show himself a young gallant! What an
unweighed behavior hath this Flemish drunkard
picked--with the devil's name!--out of my
conversation, that he dares in this manner assay me?
Why, he hath not been thrice in my company! What
should I say to him? I was then frugal of my
mirth: Heaven forgive me! Why, I'll exhibit a bill
in the parliament for the putting down of men. How
shall I be revenged on him? for revenged I will be,
as sure as his guts are made of puddings.
[Enter MISTRESS FORD]

blocks.speaker: mistressford
lines: Mistress Page! trust me, I was going to your house.

blocks.speaker: mistresspage
lines: And, trust me, I was coming to you. You look very
ill.

blocks.speaker: mistressford
lines: Nay, I'll ne'er believe that; I have to show to the contrary.

blocks.speaker: mistresspage
lines: Faith, but you do, in my mind.

blocks.speaker: mistressford
lines: Well, I do then; yet I say I could show you to the
contrary. O Mistress Page, give me some counsel!

blocks.speaker: mistresspage
lines: What's the matter, woman?

blocks.speaker: mistressford
lines: O woman, if it were not for one trifling respect, I
could come to such honour!

blocks.speaker: mistresspage
lines: Hang the trifle, woman! take the honour. What is
it? dispense with trifles; what is it?

blocks.speaker: mistressford
lines: If I would but go to hell for an eternal moment or so,
I could be knighted.

blocks.speaker: mistresspage
lines: What? thou liest! Sir Alice Ford! These knights
will hack; and so thou shouldst not alter the
article of thy gentry.

blocks.speaker: mistressford
lines: We burn daylight: here, read, read; perceive how I
might be knighted. I shall think the worse of fat
men, as long as I have an eye to make difference of
men's liking: and yet he would not swear; praised
women's modesty; and gave such orderly and
well-behaved reproof to all uncomeliness, that I
would have sworn his disposition would have gone to
the truth of his words; but they do no more adhere
and keep place together than the Hundredth Psalm to
the tune of 'Green Sleeves.' What tempest, I trow,
threw this whale, with so many tuns of oil in his
belly, ashore at Windsor? How shall I be revenged
on him? I think the best way were to entertain him
with hope, till the wicked fire of lust have melted
him in his own grease. Did you ever hear the like?

blocks.speaker: mistresspage
lines: Letter for letter, but that the name of Page and
Ford differs! To thy great comfort in this mystery
of ill opinions, here's the twin-brother of thy
letter: but let thine inherit first; for, I
protest, mine never shall. I warrant he hath a
thousand of these letters, writ with blank space for
different names--sure, more,--and these are of the
second edition: he will print them, out of doubt;
for he cares not what he puts into the press, when
he would put us two. I had rather be a giantess,
and lie under Mount Pelion. Well, I will find you
twenty lascivious turtles ere one chaste man.

blocks.speaker: mistressford
lines: Why, this is the very same; the very hand, the very
words. What doth he think of us?

blocks.speaker: mistresspage
lines: Nay, I know not: it makes me almost ready to
wrangle with mine own honesty. I'll entertain
myself like one that I am not acquainted withal;
for, sure, unless he know some strain in me, that I
know not myself, he would never have boarded me in this fury.

blocks.speaker: mistressford
lines: 'Boarding,' call you it? I'll be sure to keep him
above deck.

blocks.speaker: mistresspage
lines: So will I. if he come under my hatches, I'll never
to sea again. Let's be revenged on him: let's
appoint him a meeting; give him a show of comfort in
his suit and lead him on with a fine-baited delay,
till he hath pawned his horses to mine host of the Garter.

blocks.speaker: mistressford
lines: Nay, I will consent to act any villany against him,
that may not sully the chariness of our honesty. O,
that my husband saw this letter! it would give
eternal food to his jealousy.

blocks.speaker: mistresspage
lines: Why, look where he comes; and my good man too: he's
as far from jealousy as I am from giving him cause;
and that I hope is an unmeasurable distance.

blocks.speaker: mistressford
lines: You are the happier woman.

blocks.speaker: mistresspage
lines: Let's consult together against this greasy knight.
Come hither.
[They retire]
[Enter FORD with PISTOL, and PAGE with NYM]

blocks.speaker: ford
lines: Well, I hope it be not so.

blocks.speaker: pistol
lines: Hope is a curtal dog in some affairs:
Sir John affects thy wife.

blocks.speaker: ford
lines: Why, sir, my wife is not young.

blocks.speaker: pistol
lines: He wooes both high and low, both rich and poor,
Both young and old, one with another, Ford;
He loves the gallimaufry: Ford, perpend.

blocks.speaker: ford
lines: Love my wife!

blocks.speaker: pistol
lines: With liver burning hot. Prevent, or go thou,
Like Sir Actaeon he, with Ringwood at thy heels:
O, odious is the name!

blocks.speaker: ford
lines: What name, sir?

blocks.speaker: pistol
lines: The horn, I say. Farewell.
Take heed, have open eye, for thieves do foot by night:
Take heed, ere summer comes or cuckoo-birds do sing.
Away, Sir Corporal Nym!
Believe it, Page; he speaks sense.
[Exit]

blocks.speaker: ford
lines: [Aside] I will be patient; I will find out this.

blocks.speaker: nym
lines: [To PAGE] And this is true; I like not the humour
of lying. He hath wronged me in some humours: I
should have borne the humoured letter to her; but I
have a sword and it shall bite upon my necessity.
He loves your wife; there's the short and the long.
My name is Corporal Nym; I speak and I avouch; 'tis
true: my name is Nym and Falstaff loves your wife.
Adieu. I love not the humour of bread and cheese,
and there's the humour of it. Adieu.
[Exit]

blocks.speaker: page-mww
lines: 'The humour of it,' quoth a'! here's a fellow
frights English out of his wits.

blocks.speaker: ford
lines: I will seek out Falstaff.

blocks.speaker: page-mww
lines: I never heard such a drawling, affecting rogue.

blocks.speaker: ford
lines: If I do find it: well.

blocks.speaker: page-mww
lines: I will not believe such a Cataian, though the priest
o' the town commended him for a true man.

blocks.speaker: ford
lines: 'Twas a good sensible fellow: well.

blocks.speaker: page-mww
lines: How now, Meg!
[MISTRESS PAGE and MISTRESS FORD come forward]

blocks.speaker: mistresspage
lines: Whither go you, George? Hark you.

blocks.speaker: mistressford
lines: How now, sweet Frank! why art thou melancholy?

blocks.speaker: ford
lines: I melancholy! I am not melancholy. Get you home, go.

blocks.speaker: mistressford
lines: Faith, thou hast some crotchets in thy head. Now,
will you go, Mistress Page?

blocks.speaker: mistresspage
lines: Have with you. You'll come to dinner, George.
[Aside to MISTRESS FORD]
Look who comes yonder: she shall be our messenger
to this paltry knight.

blocks.speaker: mistressford
lines: [Aside to MISTRESS PAGE] Trust me, I thought on her:
she'll fit it.
[Enter MISTRESS QUICKLY]

blocks.speaker: mistresspage
lines: You are come to see my daughter Anne?

blocks.speaker: quickly
lines: Ay, forsooth; and, I pray, how does good Mistress Anne?

blocks.speaker: mistresspage
lines: Go in with us and see: we have an hour's talk with
you.
[Exeunt MISTRESS PAGE, MISTRESS FORD, and MISTRESS QUICKLY]

blocks.speaker: page-mww
lines: How now, Master Ford!

blocks.speaker: ford
lines: You heard what this knave told me, did you not?

blocks.speaker: page-mww
lines: Yes: and you heard what the other told me?

blocks.speaker: ford
lines: Do you think there is truth in them?

blocks.speaker: page-mww
lines: Hang 'em, slaves! I do not think the knight would
offer it: but these that accuse him in his intent
towards our wives are a yoke of his discarded men;
very rogues, now they be out of service.

blocks.speaker: ford
lines: Were they his men?

blocks.speaker: page-mww
lines: Marry, were they.

blocks.speaker: ford
lines: I like it never the better for that. Does he lie at
the Garter?

blocks.speaker: page-mww
lines: Ay, marry, does he. If he should intend this voyage
towards my wife, I would turn her loose to him; and
what he gets more of her than sharp words, let it
lie on my head.

blocks.speaker: ford
lines: I do not misdoubt my wife; but I would be loath to
turn them together. A man may be too confident: I
would have nothing lie on my head: I cannot be thus satisfied.

blocks.speaker: page-mww
lines: Look where my ranting host of the Garter comes:
there is either liquor in his pate or money in his
purse when he looks so merrily.
[Enter Host]
How now, mine host!

blocks.speaker: garterhost
lines: How now, bully-rook! thou'rt a gentleman.
Cavaleiro-justice, I say!
[Enter SHALLOW]

blocks.speaker: shallow
lines: I follow, mine host, I follow. Good even and
twenty, good Master Page! Master Page, will you go
with us? we have sport in hand.

blocks.speaker: garterhost
lines: Tell him, cavaleiro-justice; tell him, bully-rook.

blocks.speaker: shallow
lines: Sir, there is a fray to be fought between Sir Hugh
the Welsh priest and Caius the French doctor.

blocks.speaker: ford
lines: Good mine host o' the Garter, a word with you.
[Drawing him aside]

blocks.speaker: garterhost
lines: What sayest thou, my bully-rook?

blocks.speaker: shallow
lines: [To PAGE] Will you go with us to behold it? My
merry host hath had the measuring of their weapons;
and, I think, hath appointed them contrary places;
for, believe me, I hear the parson is no jester.
Hark, I will tell you what our sport shall be.
[They converse apart]

blocks.speaker: garterhost
lines: Hast thou no suit against my knight, my
guest-cavaleire?

blocks.speaker: ford
lines: None, I protest: but I'll give you a pottle of
burnt sack to give me recourse to him and tell him
my name is Brook; only for a jest.

blocks.speaker: garterhost
lines: My hand, bully; thou shalt have egress and regress;
--said I well?--and thy name shall be Brook. It is
a merry knight. Will you go, An-heires?

blocks.speaker: shallow
lines: Have with you, mine host.

blocks.speaker: page-mww
lines: I have heard the Frenchman hath good skill in
his rapier.

blocks.speaker: shallow
lines: Tut, sir, I could have told you more. In these times
you stand on distance, your passes, stoccadoes, and
I know not what: 'tis the heart, Master Page; 'tis
here, 'tis here. I have seen the time, with my long
sword I would have made you four tall fellows skip like rats.

blocks.speaker: garterhost
lines: Here, boys, here, here! shall we wag?

blocks.speaker: page-mww
lines: Have with you. I would rather hear them scold than fight.
[Exeunt Host, SHALLOW, and PAGE]

blocks.speaker: ford
lines: Though Page be a secure fool, an stands so firmly
on his wife's frailty, yet I cannot put off my
opinion so easily: she was in his company at Page's
house; and what they made there, I know not. Well,
I will look further into't: and I have a disguise
to sound Falstaff. If I find her honest, I lose not
my labour; if she be otherwise, 'tis labour well bestowed.
[Exit]

scenes.title: A room in the Garter Inn.

lines: [Enter FALSTAFF and PISTOL]

blocks.speaker: falstaff
lines: I will not lend thee a penny.

blocks.speaker: pistol
lines: Why, then the world's mine oyster.
Which I with sword will open.

blocks.speaker: falstaff
lines: Not a penny. I have been content, sir, you should
lay my countenance to pawn; I have grated upon my
good friends for three reprieves for you and your
coach-fellow Nym; or else you had looked through
the grate, like a geminy of baboons. I am damned in
hell for swearing to gentlemen my friends, you were
good soldiers and tall fellows; and when Mistress
Bridget lost the handle of her fan, I took't upon
mine honour thou hadst it not.

blocks.speaker: pistol
lines: Didst not thou share? hadst thou not fifteen pence?

blocks.speaker: falstaff
lines: Reason, you rogue, reason: thinkest thou I'll
endanger my soul gratis? At a word, hang no more
about me, I am no gibbet for you. Go. A short knife
and a throng! To your manor of Pickt-hatch! Go.
You'll not bear a letter for me, you rogue! you
stand upon your honour! Why, thou unconfinable
baseness, it is as much as I can do to keep the
terms of my honour precise: I, I, I myself
sometimes, leaving the fear of God on the left hand
and hiding mine honour in my necessity, am fain to
shuffle, to hedge and to lurch; and yet you, rogue,
will ensconce your rags, your cat-a-mountain
looks, your red-lattice phrases, and your
bold-beating oaths, under the shelter of your
honour! You will not do it, you!

blocks.speaker: pistol
lines: I do relent: what would thou more of man?
[Enter ROBIN]

blocks.speaker: robin
lines: Sir, here's a woman would speak with you.

blocks.speaker: falstaff
lines: Let her approach.
[Enter MISTRESS QUICKLY]

blocks.speaker: quickly
lines: Give your worship good morrow.

blocks.speaker: falstaff
lines: Good morrow, good wife.

blocks.speaker: quickly
lines: Not so, an't please your worship.

blocks.speaker: falstaff
lines: Good maid, then.

blocks.speaker: quickly
lines: I'll be sworn,
As my mother was, the first hour I was born.

blocks.speaker: falstaff
lines: I do believe the swearer. What with me?

blocks.speaker: quickly
lines: Shall I vouchsafe your worship a word or two?

blocks.speaker: falstaff
lines: Two thousand, fair woman: and I'll vouchsafe thee
the hearing.

blocks.speaker: quickly
lines: There is one Mistress Ford, sir:--I pray, come a
little nearer this ways:--I myself dwell with master
Doctor Caius,--

blocks.speaker: falstaff
lines: Well, on: Mistress Ford, you say,--

blocks.speaker: quickly
lines: Your worship says very true: I pray your worship,
come a little nearer this ways.

blocks.speaker: falstaff
lines: I warrant thee, nobody hears; mine own people, mine
own people.

blocks.speaker: quickly
lines: Are they so? God bless them and make them his servants!

blocks.speaker: falstaff
lines: Well, Mistress Ford; what of her?

blocks.speaker: quickly
lines: Why, sir, she's a good creature. Lord Lord! your
worship's a wanton! Well, heaven forgive you and all
of us, I pray!

blocks.speaker: falstaff
lines: Mistress Ford; come, Mistress Ford,--

blocks.speaker: quickly
lines: Marry, this is the short and the long of it; you
have brought her into such a canaries as 'tis
wonderful. The best courtier of them all, when the
court lay at Windsor, could never have brought her
to such a canary. Yet there has been knights, and
lords, and gentlemen, with their coaches, I warrant
you, coach after coach, letter after letter, gift
after gift; smelling so sweetly, all musk, and so
rushling, I warrant you, in silk and gold; and in
such alligant terms; and in such wine and sugar of
the best and the fairest, that would have won any
woman's heart; and, I warrant you, they could never
get an eye-wink of her: I had myself twenty angels
given me this morning; but I defy all angels, in
any such sort, as they say, but in the way of
honesty: and, I warrant you, they could never get
her so much as sip on a cup with the proudest of
them all: and yet there has been earls, nay, which
is more, pensioners; but, I warrant you, all is one with her.

blocks.speaker: falstaff
lines: But what says she to me? be brief, my good
she-Mercury.

blocks.speaker: quickly
lines: Marry, she hath received your letter, for the which
she thanks you a thousand times; and she gives you
to notify that her husband will be absence from his
house between ten and eleven.

blocks.speaker: falstaff
lines: Ten and eleven?

blocks.speaker: quickly
lines: Ay, forsooth; and then you may come and see the
picture, she says, that you wot of: Master Ford,
her husband, will be from home. Alas! the sweet
woman leads an ill life with him: he's a very
jealousy man: she leads a very frampold life with
him, good heart.

blocks.speaker: falstaff
lines: Ten and eleven. Woman, commend me to her; I will
not fail her.

blocks.speaker: quickly
lines: Why, you say well. But I have another messenger to
your worship. Mistress Page hath her hearty
commendations to you too: and let me tell you in
your ear, she's as fartuous a civil modest wife, and
one, I tell you, that will not miss you morning nor
evening prayer, as any is in Windsor, whoe'er be the
other: and she bade me tell your worship that her
husband is seldom from home; but she hopes there
will come a time. I never knew a woman so dote upon
a man: surely I think you have charms, la; yes, in truth.

blocks.speaker: falstaff
lines: Not I, I assure thee: setting the attractions of my
good parts aside I have no other charms.

blocks.speaker: quickly
lines: Blessing on your heart for't!

blocks.speaker: falstaff
lines: But, I pray thee, tell me this: has Ford's wife and
Page's wife acquainted each other how they love me?

blocks.speaker: quickly
lines: That were a jest indeed! they have not so little
grace, I hope: that were a trick indeed! but
Mistress Page would desire you to send her your
little page, of all loves: her husband has a
marvellous infection to the little page; and truly
Master Page is an honest man. Never a wife in
Windsor leads a better life than she does: do what
she will, say what she will, take all, pay all, go
to bed when she list, rise when she list, all is as
she will: and truly she deserves it; for if there
be a kind woman in Windsor, she is one. You must
send her your page; no remedy.

blocks.speaker: falstaff
lines: Why, I will.

blocks.speaker: quickly
lines: Nay, but do so, then: and, look you, he may come and
go between you both; and in any case have a
nay-word, that you may know one another's mind, and
the boy never need to understand any thing; for
'tis not good that children should know any
wickedness: old folks, you know, have discretion,
as they say, and know the world.

blocks.speaker: falstaff
lines: Fare thee well: commend me to them both: there's
my purse; I am yet thy debtor. Boy, go along with
this woman.
[Exeunt MISTRESS QUICKLY and ROBIN]
This news distracts me!

blocks.speaker: pistol
lines: This punk is one of Cupid's carriers:
Clap on more sails; pursue; up with your fights:
Give fire: she is my prize, or ocean whelm them all!
[Exit]

blocks.speaker: falstaff
lines: Sayest thou so, old Jack? go thy ways; I'll make
more of thy old body than I have done. Will they
yet look after thee? Wilt thou, after the expense
of so much money, be now a gainer? Good body, I
thank thee. Let them say 'tis grossly done; so it be
fairly done, no matter.
[Enter BARDOLPH]

blocks.speaker: bardolph-mww
lines: Sir John, there's one Master Brook below would fain
speak with you, and be acquainted with you; and hath
sent your worship a morning's draught of sack.

blocks.speaker: falstaff
lines: Brook is his name?

blocks.speaker: bardolph-mww
lines: Ay, sir.

blocks.speaker: falstaff
lines: Call him in.
[Exit BARDOLPH]
Such Brooks are welcome to me, that o'erflow such
liquor. Ah, ha! Mistress Ford and Mistress Page
have I encompassed you? go to; via!
[Re-enter BARDOLPH, with FORD disguised]

blocks.speaker: ford
lines: Bless you, sir!

blocks.speaker: falstaff
lines: And you, sir! Would you speak with me?

blocks.speaker: ford
lines: I make bold to press with so little preparation upon
you.

blocks.speaker: falstaff
lines: You're welcome. What's your will? Give us leave, drawer.
[Exit BARDOLPH]

blocks.speaker: ford
lines: Sir, I am a gentleman that have spent much; my name is Brook.

blocks.speaker: falstaff
lines: Good Master Brook, I desire more acquaintance of you.

blocks.speaker: ford
lines: Good Sir John, I sue for yours: not to charge you;
for I must let you understand I think myself in
better plight for a lender than you are: the which
hath something embolden'd me to this unseasoned
intrusion; for they say, if money go before, all
ways do lie open.

blocks.speaker: falstaff
lines: Money is a good soldier, sir, and will on.

blocks.speaker: ford
lines: Troth, and I have a bag of money here troubles me:
if you will help to bear it, Sir John, take all, or
half, for easing me of the carriage.

blocks.speaker: falstaff
lines: Sir, I know not how I may deserve to be your porter.

blocks.speaker: ford
lines: I will tell you, sir, if you will give me the hearing.

blocks.speaker: falstaff
lines: Speak, good Master Brook: I shall be glad to be
your servant.

blocks.speaker: ford
lines: Sir, I hear you are a scholar,--I will be brief
with you,--and you have been a man long known to me,
though I had never so good means, as desire, to make
myself acquainted with you. I shall discover a
thing to you, wherein I must very much lay open mine
own imperfection: but, good Sir John, as you have
one eye upon my follies, as you hear them unfolded,
turn another into the register of your own; that I
may pass with a reproof the easier, sith you
yourself know how easy it is to be such an offender.

blocks.speaker: falstaff
lines: Very well, sir; proceed.

blocks.speaker: ford
lines: There is a gentlewoman in this town; her husband's
name is Ford.

blocks.speaker: falstaff
lines: Well, sir.

blocks.speaker: ford
lines: I have long loved her, and, I protest to you,
bestowed much on her; followed her with a doting
observance; engrossed opportunities to meet her;
fee'd every slight occasion that could but niggardly
give me sight of her; not only bought many presents
to give her, but have given largely to many to know
what she would have given; briefly, I have pursued
her as love hath pursued me; which hath been on the
wing of all occasions. But whatsoever I have
merited, either in my mind or, in my means, meed,
I am sure, I have received none; unless experience
be a jewel that I have purchased at an infinite
rate, and that hath taught me to say this:
'Love like a shadow flies when substance love pursues;
Pursuing that that flies, and flying what pursues.'

blocks.speaker: falstaff
lines: Have you received no promise of satisfaction at her hands?

blocks.speaker: ford
lines: Never.

blocks.speaker: falstaff
lines: Have you importuned her to such a purpose?

blocks.speaker: ford
lines: Never.

blocks.speaker: falstaff
lines: Of what quality was your love, then?

blocks.speaker: ford
lines: Like a fair house built on another man's ground; so
that I have lost my edifice by mistaking the place
where I erected it.

blocks.speaker: falstaff
lines: To what purpose have you unfolded this to me?

blocks.speaker: ford
lines: When I have told you that, I have told you all.
Some say, that though she appear honest to me, yet in
other places she enlargeth her mirth so far that
there is shrewd construction made of her. Now, Sir
John, here is the heart of my purpose: you are a
gentleman of excellent breeding, admirable
discourse, of great admittance, authentic in your
place and person, generally allowed for your many
war-like, court-like, and learned preparations.

blocks.speaker: falstaff
lines: O, sir!

blocks.speaker: ford
lines: Believe it, for you know it. There is money; spend
it, spend it; spend more; spend all I have; only
give me so much of your time in exchange of it, as
to lay an amiable siege to the honesty of this
Ford's wife: use your art of wooing; win her to
consent to you: if any man may, you may as soon as
any.

blocks.speaker: falstaff
lines: Would it apply well to the vehemency of your
affection, that I should win what you would enjoy?
Methinks you prescribe to yourself very preposterously.

blocks.speaker: ford
lines: O, understand my drift. She dwells so securely on
the excellency of her honour, that the folly of my
soul dares not present itself: she is too bright to
be looked against. Now, could I could come to her
with any detection in my hand, my desires had
instance and argument to commend themselves: I
could drive her then from the ward of her purity,
her reputation, her marriage-vow, and a thousand
other her defences, which now are too too strongly
embattled against me. What say you to't, Sir John?

blocks.speaker: falstaff
lines: Master Brook, I will first make bold with your
money; next, give me your hand; and last, as I am a
gentleman, you shall, if you will, enjoy Ford's wife.

blocks.speaker: ford
lines: O good sir!

blocks.speaker: falstaff
lines: I say you shall.

blocks.speaker: ford
lines: Want no money, Sir John; you shall want none.

blocks.speaker: falstaff
lines: Want no Mistress Ford, Master Brook; you shall want
none. I shall be with her, I may tell you, by her
own appointment; even as you came in to me, her
assistant or go-between parted from me: I say I
shall be with her between ten and eleven; for at
that time the jealous rascally knave her husband
will be forth. Come you to me at night; you shall
know how I speed.

blocks.speaker: ford
lines: I am blest in your acquaintance. Do you know Ford,
sir?

blocks.speaker: falstaff
lines: Hang him, poor cuckoldly knave! I know him not:
yet I wrong him to call him poor; they say the
jealous wittolly knave hath masses of money; for the
which his wife seems to me well-favored. I will
use her as the key of the cuckoldly rogue's coffer;
and there's my harvest-home.

blocks.speaker: ford
lines: I would you knew Ford, sir, that you might avoid him
if you saw him.

blocks.speaker: falstaff
lines: Hang him, mechanical salt-butter rogue! I will
stare him out of his wits; I will awe him with my
cudgel: it shall hang like a meteor o'er the
cuckold's horns. Master Brook, thou shalt know I
will predominate over the peasant, and thou shalt
lie with his wife. Come to me soon at night.
Ford's a knave, and I will aggravate his style;
thou, Master Brook, shalt know him for knave and
cuckold. Come to me soon at night.
[Exit]

blocks.speaker: ford
lines: What a damned Epicurean rascal is this! My heart is
ready to crack with impatience. Who says this is
improvident jealousy? my wife hath sent to him; the
hour is fixed; the match is made. Would any man
have thought this? See the hell of having a false
woman! My bed shall be abused, my coffers
ransacked, my reputation gnawn at; and I shall not
only receive this villanous wrong, but stand under
the adoption of abominable terms, and by him that
does me this wrong. Terms! names! Amaimon sounds
well; Lucifer, well; Barbason, well; yet they are
devils' additions, the names of fiends: but
Cuckold! Wittol!--Cuckold! the devil himself hath
not such a name. Page is an ass, a secure ass: he
will trust his wife; he will not be jealous. I will
rather trust a Fleming with my butter, Parson Hugh
the Welshman with my cheese, an Irishman with my
aqua-vitae bottle, or a thief to walk my ambling
gelding, than my wife with herself; then she plots,
then she ruminates, then she devises; and what they
think in their hearts they may effect, they will
break their hearts but they will effect. God be
praised for my jealousy! Eleven o'clock the hour.
I will prevent this, detect my wife, be revenged on
Falstaff, and laugh at Page. I will about it;
better three hours too soon than a minute too late.
Fie, fie, fie! cuckold! cuckold! cuckold!
[Exit]
[Enter DOCTOR CAIUS and RUGBY]

blocks.speaker: doctorcaius
lines: Jack Rugby!

blocks.speaker: rugby
lines: Sir?

blocks.speaker: doctorcaius
lines: Vat is de clock, Jack?

blocks.speaker: rugby
lines: 'Tis past the hour, sir, that Sir Hugh promised to meet.

blocks.speaker: doctorcaius
lines: By gar, he has save his soul, dat he is no come; he
has pray his Pible well, dat he is no come: by gar,
Jack Rugby, he is dead already, if he be come.

blocks.speaker: rugby
lines: He is wise, sir; he knew your worship would kill
him, if he came.

blocks.speaker: doctorcaius
lines: By gar, de herring is no dead so as I vill kill him.
Take your rapier, Jack; I vill tell you how I vill kill him.

blocks.speaker: rugby
lines: Alas, sir, I cannot fence.

blocks.speaker: doctorcaius
lines: Villany, take your rapier.

blocks.speaker: rugby
lines: Forbear; here's company.
[Enter Host, SHALLOW, SLENDER, and PAGE]

blocks.speaker: garterhost
lines: Bless thee, bully doctor!

blocks.speaker: shallow
lines: Save you, Master Doctor Caius!

blocks.speaker: page-mww
lines: Now, good master doctor!

blocks.speaker: slender
lines: Give you good morrow, sir.

blocks.speaker: doctorcaius
lines: Vat be all you, one, two, tree, four, come for?

blocks.speaker: garterhost
lines: To see thee fight, to see thee foin, to see thee
traverse; to see thee here, to see thee there; to
see thee pass thy punto, thy stock, thy reverse, thy
distance, thy montant. Is he dead, my Ethiopian? is
he dead, my Francisco? ha, bully! What says my
AEsculapius? my Galen? my heart of elder? ha! is
he dead, bully stale? is he dead?

blocks.speaker: doctorcaius
lines: By gar, he is de coward Jack priest of de vorld; he
is not show his face.

blocks.speaker: garterhost
lines: Thou art a Castalion-King-Urinal. Hector of Greece, my boy!

blocks.speaker: doctorcaius
lines: I pray you, bear vitness that me have stay six or
seven, two, tree hours for him, and he is no come.

blocks.speaker: shallow
lines: He is the wiser man, master doctor: he is a curer of
souls, and you a curer of bodies; if you should
fight, you go against the hair of your professions.
Is it not true, Master Page?

blocks.speaker: page-mww
lines: Master Shallow, you have yourself been a great
fighter, though now a man of peace.

blocks.speaker: shallow
lines: Bodykins, Master Page, though I now be old and of
the peace, if I see a sword out, my finger itches to
make one. Though we are justices and doctors and
churchmen, Master Page, we have some salt of our
youth in us; we are the sons of women, Master Page.

blocks.speaker: page-mww
lines: 'Tis true, Master Shallow.

blocks.speaker: shallow
lines: It will be found so, Master Page. Master Doctor
Caius, I am come to fetch you home. I am sworn of
the peace: you have showed yourself a wise
physician, and Sir Hugh hath shown himself a wise
and patient churchman. You must go with me, master doctor.

blocks.speaker: garterhost
lines: Pardon, guest-justice. A word, Mounseur Mockwater.

blocks.speaker: doctorcaius
lines: Mock-vater! vat is dat?

blocks.speaker: garterhost
lines: Mock-water, in our English tongue, is valour, bully.

blocks.speaker: doctorcaius
lines: By gar, den, I have as mush mock-vater as de
Englishman. Scurvy jack-dog priest! by gar, me
vill cut his ears.

blocks.speaker: garterhost
lines: He will clapper-claw thee tightly, bully.

blocks.speaker: doctorcaius
lines: Clapper-de-claw! vat is dat?

blocks.speaker: garterhost
lines: That is, he will make thee amends.

blocks.speaker: doctorcaius
lines: By gar, me do look he shall clapper-de-claw me;
for, by gar, me vill have it.

blocks.speaker: garterhost
lines: And I will provoke him to't, or let him wag.

blocks.speaker: doctorcaius
lines: Me tank you for dat.

blocks.speaker: garterhost
lines: And, moreover, bully,--but first, master guest, and
Master Page, and eke Cavaleiro Slender, go you
through the town to Frogmore.
[Aside to them]

blocks.speaker: page-mww
lines: Sir Hugh is there, is he?

blocks.speaker: garterhost
lines: He is there: see what humour he is in; and I will
bring the doctor about by the fields. Will it do well?

blocks.speaker: shallow
lines: We will do it.

blocks.speaker: page-mww
lines: [with Shallow and Slender] Adieu, good master doctor.
[Exeunt PAGE, SHALLOW, and SLENDER]

blocks.speaker: doctorcaius
lines: By gar, me vill kill de priest; for he speak for a
jack-an-ape to Anne Page.

blocks.speaker: garterhost
lines: Let him die: sheathe thy impatience, throw cold
water on thy choler: go about the fields with me
through Frogmore: I will bring thee where Mistress
Anne Page is, at a farm-house a-feasting; and thou
shalt woo her. Cried I aim? said I well?

blocks.speaker: doctorcaius
lines: By gar, me dank you for dat: by gar, I love you;
and I shall procure-a you de good guest, de earl,
de knight, de lords, de gentlemen, my patients.

blocks.speaker: garterhost
lines: For the which I will be thy adversary toward Anne
Page. Said I well?

blocks.speaker: doctorcaius
lines: By gar, 'tis good; vell said.

blocks.speaker: garterhost
lines: Let us wag, then.

blocks.speaker: doctorcaius
lines: Come at my heels, Jack Rugby.
[Exeunt]
[Enter SIR HUGH EVANS and SIMPLE]

blocks.speaker: sirhugh
lines: I pray you now, good master Slender's serving-man,
and friend Simple by your name, which way have you
looked for Master Caius, that calls himself doctor of physic?

blocks.speaker: simple
lines: Marry, sir, the pittie-ward, the park-ward, every
way; old Windsor way, and every way but the town
way.

blocks.speaker: sirhugh
lines: I most fehemently desire you you will also look that
way.

blocks.speaker: simple
lines: I will, sir.
[Exit]

blocks.speaker: sirhugh
lines: 'Pless my soul, how full of chollors I am, and
trempling of mind! I shall be glad if he have
deceived me. How melancholies I am! I will knog
his urinals about his knave's costard when I have
good opportunities for the ork. 'Pless my soul!
[Sings]
To shallow rivers, to whose falls
Melodious birds sings madrigals;
There will we make our peds of roses,
And a thousand fragrant posies.
To shallow--
Mercy on me! I have a great dispositions to cry.
[Sings]
Melodious birds sing madrigals--
When as I sat in Pabylon--
And a thousand vagram posies.
To shallow &c.
[Re-enter SIMPLE]

blocks.speaker: simple
lines: Yonder he is coming, this way, Sir Hugh.

blocks.speaker: sirhugh
lines: He's welcome.
[Sings]
To shallow rivers, to whose falls-
Heaven prosper the right! What weapons is he?

blocks.speaker: simple
lines: No weapons, sir. There comes my master, Master
Shallow, and another gentleman, from Frogmore, over
the stile, this way.

blocks.speaker: sirhugh
lines: Pray you, give me my gown; or else keep it in your arms.
[Enter PAGE, SHALLOW, and SLENDER]

blocks.speaker: shallow
lines: How now, master Parson! Good morrow, good Sir Hugh.
Keep a gamester from the dice, and a good student
from his book, and it is wonderful.

blocks.speaker: slender
lines: [Aside] Ah, sweet Anne Page!

blocks.speaker: page-mww
lines: 'Save you, good Sir Hugh!

blocks.speaker: sirhugh
lines: 'Pless you from his mercy sake, all of you!

blocks.speaker: shallow
lines: What, the sword and the word! do you study them
both, master parson?

blocks.speaker: page-mww
lines: And youthful still! in your doublet and hose this
raw rheumatic day!

blocks.speaker: sirhugh
lines: There is reasons and causes for it.

blocks.speaker: page-mww
lines: We are come to you to do a good office, master parson.

blocks.speaker: sirhugh
lines: Fery well: what is it?

blocks.speaker: page-mww
lines: Yonder is a most reverend gentleman, who, belike
having received wrong by some person, is at most
odds with his own gravity and patience that ever you
saw.

blocks.speaker: shallow
lines: I have lived fourscore years and upward; I never
heard a man of his place, gravity and learning, so
wide of his own respect.

blocks.speaker: sirhugh
lines: What is he?

blocks.speaker: page-mww
lines: I think you know him; Master Doctor Caius, the
renowned French physician.

blocks.speaker: sirhugh
lines: Got's will, and his passion of my heart! I had as
lief you would tell me of a mess of porridge.

blocks.speaker: page-mww
lines: Why?

blocks.speaker: sirhugh
lines: He has no more knowledge in Hibocrates and Galen,
--and he is a knave besides; a cowardly knave as you
would desires to be acquainted withal.

blocks.speaker: page-mww
lines: I warrant you, he's the man should fight with him.

blocks.speaker: shallow
lines: [Aside] O sweet Anne Page!

blocks.speaker: shallow
lines: It appears so by his weapons. Keep them asunder:
here comes Doctor Caius.
[Enter Host, DOCTOR CAIUS, and RUGBY]

blocks.speaker: page-mww
lines: Nay, good master parson, keep in your weapon.

blocks.speaker: shallow
lines: So do you, good master doctor.

blocks.speaker: garterhost
lines: Disarm them, and let them question: let them keep
their limbs whole and hack our English.

blocks.speaker: doctorcaius
lines: I pray you, let-a me speak a word with your ear.
Vherefore vill you not meet-a me?

blocks.speaker: sirhugh
lines: [Aside to DOCTOR CAIUS] Pray you, use your patience:
in good time.

blocks.speaker: doctorcaius
lines: By gar, you are de coward, de Jack dog, John ape.

blocks.speaker: sirhugh
lines: [Aside to DOCTOR CAIUS] Pray you let us not be
laughing-stocks to other men's humours; I desire you
in friendship, and I will one way or other make you amends.
[Aloud]
I will knog your urinals about your knave's cockscomb
for missing your meetings and appointments.

blocks.speaker: doctorcaius
lines: Diable! Jack Rugby,--mine host de Jarteer,--have I
not stay for him to kill him? have I not, at de place
I did appoint?

blocks.speaker: sirhugh
lines: As I am a Christians soul now, look you, this is the
place appointed: I'll be judgement by mine host of
the Garter.

blocks.speaker: garterhost
lines: Peace, I say, Gallia and Gaul, French and Welsh,
soul-curer and body-curer!

blocks.speaker: doctorcaius
lines: Ay, dat is very good; excellent.

blocks.speaker: garterhost
lines: Peace, I say! hear mine host of the Garter. Am I
politic? am I subtle? am I a Machiavel? Shall I
lose my doctor? no; he gives me the potions and the
motions. Shall I lose my parson, my priest, my Sir
Hugh? no; he gives me the proverbs and the
no-verbs. Give me thy hand, terrestrial; so. Give me
thy hand, celestial; so. Boys of art, I have
deceived you both; I have directed you to wrong
places: your hearts are mighty, your skins are
whole, and let burnt sack be the issue. Come, lay
their swords to pawn. Follow me, lads of peace;
follow, follow, follow.

blocks.speaker: shallow
lines: Trust me, a mad host. Follow, gentlemen, follow.

blocks.speaker: slender
lines: [Aside] O sweet Anne Page!
[Exeunt SHALLOW, SLENDER, PAGE, and Host]

blocks.speaker: doctorcaius
lines: Ha, do I perceive dat? have you make-a de sot of
us, ha, ha?

blocks.speaker: sirhugh
lines: This is well; he has made us his vlouting-stog. I
desire you that we may be friends; and let us knog
our prains together to be revenge on this same
scall, scurvy cogging companion, the host of the Garter.

blocks.speaker: doctorcaius
lines: By gar, with all my heart. He promise to bring me
where is Anne Page; by gar, he deceive me too.

blocks.speaker: sirhugh
lines: Well, I will smite his noddles. Pray you, follow.
[Exeunt]
[Enter MISTRESS PAGE and ROBIN]

blocks.speaker: mistresspage
lines: Nay, keep your way, little gallant; you were wont to
be a follower, but now you are a leader. Whether
had you rather lead mine eyes, or eye your master's heels?

blocks.speaker: robin
lines: I had rather, forsooth, go before you like a man
than follow him like a dwarf.

blocks.speaker: mistresspage
lines: O, you are a flattering boy: now I see you'll be a courtier.
[Enter FORD]

blocks.speaker: ford
lines: Well met, Mistress Page. Whither go you?

blocks.speaker: mistresspage
lines: Truly, sir, to see your wife. Is she at home?

blocks.speaker: ford
lines: Ay; and as idle as she may hang together, for want
of company. I think, if your husbands were dead,
you two would marry.

blocks.speaker: mistresspage
lines: Be sure of that,--two other husbands.

blocks.speaker: ford
lines: Where had you this pretty weather-cock?

blocks.speaker: mistresspage
lines: I cannot tell what the dickens his name is my
husband had him of. What do you call your knight's
name, sirrah?

blocks.speaker: robin
lines: Sir John Falstaff.

blocks.speaker: ford
lines: Sir John Falstaff!

blocks.speaker: mistresspage
lines: He, he; I can never hit on's name. There is such a
league between my good man and he! Is your wife at
home indeed?

blocks.speaker: ford
lines: Indeed she is.

blocks.speaker: mistresspage
lines: By your leave, sir: I am sick till I see her.
[Exeunt MISTRESS PAGE and ROBIN]

blocks.speaker: ford
lines: Has Page any brains? hath he any eyes? hath he any
thinking? Sure, they sleep; he hath no use of them.
Why, this boy will carry a letter twenty mile, as
easy as a cannon will shoot point-blank twelve
score. He pieces out his wife's inclination; he
gives her folly motion and advantage: and now she's
going to my wife, and Falstaff's boy with her. A
man may hear this shower sing in the wind. And
Falstaff's boy with her! Good plots, they are laid;
and our revolted wives share damnation together.
Well; I will take him, then torture my wife, pluck
the borrowed veil of modesty from the so seeming
Mistress Page, divulge Page himself for a secure and
wilful Actaeon; and to these violent proceedings all
my neighbours shall cry aim.
[Clock heard]
The clock gives me my cue, and my assurance bids me
search: there I shall find Falstaff: I shall be
rather praised for this than mocked; for it is as
positive as the earth is firm that Falstaff is
there: I will go.
[Enter PAGE, SHALLOW, SLENDER, Host,]
SIR HUGH EVANS, DOCTOR CAIUS, and RUGBY]

blocks.speaker: shallow
lines: [with Page and others] Well met, Master Ford.

blocks.speaker: ford
lines: Trust me, a good knot: I have good cheer at home;
and I pray you all go with me.

blocks.speaker: shallow
lines: I must excuse myself, Master Ford.

blocks.speaker: slender
lines: And so must I, sir: we have appointed to dine with
Mistress Anne, and I would not break with her for
more money than I'll speak of.

blocks.speaker: shallow
lines: We have lingered about a match between Anne Page and
my cousin Slender, and this day we shall have our answer.

blocks.speaker: slender
lines: I hope I have your good will, father Page.

blocks.speaker: page-mww
lines: You have, Master Slender; I stand wholly for you:
but my wife, master doctor, is for you altogether.

blocks.speaker: doctorcaius
lines: Ay, be-gar; and de maid is love-a me: my nursh-a
Quickly tell me so mush.

blocks.speaker: garterhost
lines: What say you to young Master Fenton? he capers, he
dances, he has eyes of youth, he writes verses, he
speaks holiday, he smells April and May: he will
carry't, he will carry't; 'tis in his buttons; he
will carry't.

blocks.speaker: page-mww
lines: Not by my consent, I promise you. The gentleman is
of no having: he kept company with the wild prince
and Poins; he is of too high a region; he knows too
much. No, he shall not knit a knot in his fortunes
with the finger of my substance: if he take her,
let him take her simply; the wealth I have waits on
my consent, and my consent goes not that way.

blocks.speaker: ford
lines: I beseech you heartily, some of you go home with me
to dinner: besides your cheer, you shall have
sport; I will show you a monster. Master doctor,
you shall go; so shall you, Master Page; and you, Sir Hugh.

blocks.speaker: shallow
lines: Well, fare you well: we shall have the freer wooing
at Master Page's.
[Exeunt SHALLOW, and SLENDER]

blocks.speaker: doctorcaius
lines: Go home, John Rugby; I come anon.
[Exit RUGBY]

blocks.speaker: garterhost
lines: Farewell, my hearts: I will to my honest knight
Falstaff, and drink canary with him.
[Exit]

blocks.speaker: ford
lines: [Aside] I think I shall drink in pipe wine first
with him; I'll make him dance. Will you go, gentles?

blocks.speaker: all-mww
lines: Have with you to see this monster.
[Exeunt]
[Enter MISTRESS FORD and MISTRESS PAGE]

blocks.speaker: mistressford
lines: What, John! What, Robert!

blocks.speaker: mistresspage
lines: Quickly, quickly! is the buck-basket--

blocks.speaker: mistressford
lines: I warrant. What, Robin, I say!
[Enter Servants with a basket]

blocks.speaker: mistresspage
lines: Come, come, come.

blocks.speaker: mistressford
lines: Here, set it down.

blocks.speaker: mistresspage
lines: Give your men the charge; we must be brief.

blocks.speaker: mistressford
lines: Marry, as I told you before, John and Robert, be
ready here hard by in the brew-house: and when I
suddenly call you, come forth, and without any pause
or staggering take this basket on your shoulders:
that done, trudge with it in all haste, and carry
it among the whitsters in Datchet-mead, and there
empty it in the muddy ditch close by the Thames side.

blocks.speaker: mistresspage
lines: You will do it?

blocks.speaker: mistressford
lines: I ha' told them over and over; they lack no
direction. Be gone, and come when you are called.
[Exeunt Servants]

blocks.speaker: mistresspage
lines: Here comes little Robin.
[Enter ROBIN]

blocks.speaker: mistressford
lines: How now, my eyas-musket! what news with you?

blocks.speaker: robin
lines: My master, Sir John, is come in at your back-door,
Mistress Ford, and requests your company.

blocks.speaker: mistresspage
lines: You little Jack-a-Lent, have you been true to us?

blocks.speaker: robin
lines: Ay, I'll be sworn. My master knows not of your
being here and hath threatened to put me into
everlasting liberty if I tell you of it; for he
swears he'll turn me away.

blocks.speaker: mistresspage
lines: Thou'rt a good boy: this secrecy of thine shall be
a tailor to thee and shall make thee a new doublet
and hose. I'll go hide me.

blocks.speaker: mistressford
lines: Do so. Go tell thy master I am alone.
[Exit ROBIN]
Mistress Page, remember you your cue.

blocks.speaker: mistresspage
lines: I warrant thee; if I do not act it, hiss me.
[Exit]

blocks.speaker: mistressford
lines: Go to, then: we'll use this unwholesome humidity,
this gross watery pumpion; we'll teach him to know
turtles from jays.
[Enter FALSTAFF]

blocks.speaker: falstaff
lines: Have I caught thee, my heavenly jewel? Why, now let
me die, for I have lived long enough: this is the
period of my ambition: O this blessed hour!

blocks.speaker: mistressford
lines: O sweet Sir John!

blocks.speaker: falstaff
lines: Mistress Ford, I cannot cog, I cannot prate,
Mistress Ford. Now shall I sin in my wish: I would
thy husband were dead: I'll speak it before the
best lord; I would make thee my lady.

blocks.speaker: mistressford
lines: I your lady, Sir John! alas, I should be a pitiful lady!

blocks.speaker: falstaff
lines: Let the court of France show me such another. I see
how thine eye would emulate the diamond: thou hast
the right arched beauty of the brow that becomes the
ship-tire, the tire-valiant, or any tire of
Venetian admittance.

blocks.speaker: mistressford
lines: A plain kerchief, Sir John: my brows become nothing
else; nor that well neither.

blocks.speaker: falstaff
lines: By the Lord, thou art a traitor to say so: thou
wouldst make an absolute courtier; and the firm
fixture of thy foot would give an excellent motion
to thy gait in a semi-circled farthingale. I see
what thou wert, if Fortune thy foe were not, Nature
thy friend. Come, thou canst not hide it.

blocks.speaker: mistressford
lines: Believe me, there is no such thing in me.

blocks.speaker: falstaff
lines: What made me love thee? let that persuade thee
there's something extraordinary in thee. Come, I
cannot cog and say thou art this and that, like a
many of these lisping hawthorn-buds, that come like
women in men's apparel, and smell like Bucklersbury
in simple time; I cannot: but I love thee; none
but thee; and thou deservest it.

blocks.speaker: mistressford
lines: Do not betray me, sir. I fear you love Mistress Page.

blocks.speaker: falstaff
lines: Thou mightst as well say I love to walk by the
Counter-gate, which is as hateful to me as the reek
of a lime-kiln.

blocks.speaker: mistressford
lines: Well, heaven knows how I love you; and you shall one
day find it.

blocks.speaker: falstaff
lines: Keep in that mind; I'll deserve it.

blocks.speaker: mistressford
lines: Nay, I must tell you, so you do; or else I could not
be in that mind.

blocks.speaker: robin
lines: [Within] Mistress Ford, Mistress Ford! here's
Mistress Page at the door, sweating and blowing and
looking wildly, and would needs speak with you presently.

blocks.speaker: falstaff
lines: She shall not see me: I will ensconce me behind the arras.

blocks.speaker: mistressford
lines: Pray you, do so: she's a very tattling woman.
[FALSTAFF hides himself]
[Re-enter MISTRESS PAGE and ROBIN]
What's the matter? how now!
